channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In New York City, Pandemic Job Losses Linger
item.description: Even as the country as a whole has recovered all of the jobs it lost during the pandemic, the city is still missing 176,000 — the slowest recovery of any major metropolitan area.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Matthew Haag
item.category: New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The amount of international tourists, business travelers and commuters in New York has yet to return to its prepandemic level, hurting the workers who serve them.

item.title: Inflation Report Dampens Biden’s Claims of Economic Progress
item.description: The president is trying once again to accentuate the positives in the recovery from recession, but stubbornly high prices are complicating the message.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s attempt to celebrate the economy is defused by inflation report.

item.title: Social Security’s Cost-of-Living Increase Will Be Largest in Four Decades, an Estimate Says
item.description: Retirees will learn the amount of the increase for 2023 in October, and the current estimate is that it will be 8.7%.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.media:credit: Valerie Macon/AFP, via Getty Images
item.media:description: More than 70 million people — including retirees, those receiving disability and very low-income Americans — will be affected by the benefit increase.

item.title: Ostracized by the West, Russia Finds a Partner in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The two oil-producing countries have extended their partnership even as the United States and Europe have sought to punish and isolate Russia for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yuri Kadobnov
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. The leaders have worked together to prop up global oil prices.

item.title: How Fierce Primaries, Abortion and Inflation Transformed the 2022 Map
item.description: Democrats enter the final sprint to November more optimistic than expected, especially in the race for the Senate. But Republicans remain bullish that they can sweep into a House majority.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Delaware were the last to cast ballots during a contentious primary season.

item.title: Who Won and Lost in New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Delaware
item.description: Here is a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Don Bolduc cheered with supporters during his campaign watch party.

item.title: Was Elizabeth the Queen of America? This Week It Seemed Like It.
item.description: More than two centuries after Americans fought for freedom from the British crown, their descendants are absorbed by the latest chapter in the royal family’s drama.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: People paid their respects outside the British Embassy in Washington after the death of Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday.

item.title: How King Charles Turned His Royal Estate Into a Lucrative Portfolio
item.description: As prince, Charles used tax breaks, offshore accounts and canny real estate investments to turn a sleepy estate into a billion-dollar business.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III spent years turning his royal estate into a billion-dollar portfolio.

item.title: They Translated ‘Hamilton’ Into German. Was It Easy? Nein.
item.description: For the musical’s Hamburg premiere, a team wrestled with language and cultural differences to bring the story alive for a new audience.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Florian Thoss for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gino Emnes (Aaron Burr) and Benet Monteiro (Alexander Hamilton) are in the German production of “Hamilton.”

item.title: Six Lyrics That Show Why ‘Hamilton’ Is Tough to Translate
item.description: A direct transfer of words was never going to work for such a complex show. So the team involved got creative.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Clay Hickson

item.title: Republicans Struggle to Unite Party Around National Abortion Restrictions
item.description: A new proposal was intended to align Republicans on abortion policy before the midterm elections. It only exposed divisions.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham introducing a Republican abortion bill at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: What a High-Risk Pregnancy Looks Like After Dobbs
item.description: The photographer Stephanie Sinclair captured the newly unsettled world inside the Cleveland Clinic, where Ohio’s abortion laws have drastically changed maternal care.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Sinclair and Jaime Lowe

item.title: Durham Inquiry Appears to Wind Down as Grand Jury Expires
item.description: The special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to examine the Russia investigation seems to be wrapping up its work with no further charges in store.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner, Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: John H. Durham, center right, the special counsel examining the origins of the Russia investigation, will deliver a final report this year. Attorney General Merrick B. Garland will ultimately decide whether to make its findings public.

item.title: Where the New Climate Law Means More Drilling, Not Less
item.description: A compromise built into the law ensures oil and gas leasing in the Gulf of Mexico for the next decade. Activists say the region has been “sacrificed” to fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Bryan Tarnowski

item.title: An Oily Challenge: Evict Stinky Old Furnaces in Favor of Heat Pumps
item.description: Building by building, New York and other cities are trying to stop the age-old use of fossil fuels to heat homes and buildings. In the U.S., new climate laws aim to speed things up.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tami Nelson helps install wiring for heat pumps in her 100-year-old Brooklyn brownstone.

item.title: Braving the Winds on a Greek Isle
item.description: ‘We had been expecting Tinos’s famous Meltemi, the seasonal and often fierce northern winds that blow through the islands in the summer, to cool us down after a suffocating Roman heat wave. But not this.’
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tinos, the third largest island in the Cyclades, was known in antiquity as “the island of the winds.”

item.title: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
item.description: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lines from President Biden’s teleprompter during a speech in Maryland in August.

item.title: China Is Running Covert Operations That Could Seriously Overwhelm Us
item.description: The West isn’t nearly prepared enough for the scale and complexity of China’s all-of-nation covert offensive.
item.dc:creator: Nigel Inkster
item.media:credit: Anson Chan

item.title: Why Aren’t You Voting in Your Financial Self-Interest?
item.description: The conflict between elites and populists may not be what it seems.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: After Dobbs: Does ‘Big Tent’ Feminism Exist? Should It?
item.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter and Tressie McMillan Cottom on the future of the feminist movement.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Bettmann Archive/Getty Images

item.title: Ukraine’s Achievement Is Biden’s, Too
item.description: As Russian troops flee their positions, now is the time to press the military advantage.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier waves to passing buses near the recaptured village of Verbivka, Ukraine.

item.title: A 10-Year-Old Refugee Has Met a Million People. How Will New York Welcome Her?
item.description: She invites us to remember the big idea on which the city was built. And what the city still aspires to.
item.dc:creator: Amir Nizar Zuabi

item.title: Bill Gates: ‘We’re in a Worse Place Than I Expected’
item.description: The philanthropist on how the pandemic and the effects of the war in Ukraine are setting back progress.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images

item.title: Putin Will Make People Choose Between Heating or Eating This Winter
item.description: To defeat petro-Putinism in Europe, U.S. energy policy has to be the arsenal of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Etienne De Malglaive/Getty Images

item.title: Poverty, Plunging
item.description: Child poverty in the U.S. has fallen by more than half since the early 1990s.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: The College Pricing Game
item.description: In the wake of student debt relief, an exploration of how higher education costs became such a complex issue.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Jessica Cheung, Eric Krupke, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yale’s Sterling Memorial Library. While President Biden has tackled the issue of student debt, he has not yet taken on the soaring cost of college.

item.title: Join Al Gore and John Kerry for a Times Climate Event
item.description: How does climate change exacerbate other global challenges? Join us remotely or in person for our climate event series, with an upcoming gathering in New York in September.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Did Hurricanes Sandy or Ida Damage Your Housing? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: We want to hear the stories of people in the New York City metro area who were affected by both storms.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: E.U. Scores Major Legal Victory Against Google
item.description: A court rejected Google’s appeal of a record-setting antitrust fine related to Android and online search.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Stephanie Lecocq/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager has led the European Commission’s efforts to regulate tech giants like Amazon, Apple, Google and Meta.

item.title: Ken Starr, Independent Counsel in Clinton Investigation, Dies at 76
item.description: Mr. Starr’s investigation into President Clinton’s affair with a former White House intern propelled issues of sex and morality to the center of American life for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Joshua Brigh​t / Guardian/ eyevine / Redux
item.media:description: Ken Starr uncovered President Bill Clinton’s affair with a White House intern.

item.title: Europe Plans to Ban Goods Made With Forced Labor
item.description: While it does not explicitly mention Xinjiang, the western Chinese region where Uyghurs are believed to be pressed to work in camps, the proposal is widely seen as being aimed at Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, the E.U. trade chief, said that the European Commission had been “very careful to make sure that what we are doing is compatible” with World Trade Organization rules.

item.title: Hermès Bags and Millions in Cash: The Fall of Malaysia’s Najib Razak
item.description: The former prime minister and his wife were once seen as untouchable. Now, both have been found guilty in connection with the 1MDB financial scandal.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Fazry Ismail/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Najib Razak, the former prime minister of Malaysia, arriving to court in Putrajaya, Malaysia, last month.

item.title: Lymphatic Drainage: Does it Work? And How to Do It Yourself
item.description: These wellness practices — which center on one invisible network of vessels and nodes — have soared in popularity in recent years. Should you try them?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Heather Sten for The New York Times

item.title: How to Cope With Financial Stress
item.description: Experts share tips on how to feel empowered and manage stress as prices continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Jam Dong

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Waist Trainers Work?
item.description: Some claim the corset-like garments help wearers slim their midsections. Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie, Photograph by Shutterstock

item.title: How to Handle Menopause Symptoms While Working
item.description: Hot flashes, mood swings and other signs of menopause can cause women to quit their jobs. Here’s how some handle symptoms while working.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Gracey Zhang

item.title: Opening Old Wounds as the Man Who Warned About the Holocaust
item.description: In the solo play “Remember This,” David Strathairn portrays Jan Karski, a witness to the Nazi genocide during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: Remember This: The Lesson of Jan Karski (Play)
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Do we impart horror upon our children? Or do we want to protect them?” David Strathairn asked recently, reflecting on the challenges of talking about the atrocities of the Holocaust.
